ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would NOT recommend working on a show with Daniel as the director. He is a wonderful, intelligent person, but not a good director. While we created a wonderful show, the process was unnecessarily challenging because he is not a good leader or manager.
If you like theater, yep yep!
I don't know if they'll offer it again....but sure? Caucasian Chalk Circle was a blast.

Doing a production seminar with Larlham is great. He takes risks and works on his feet. Do it if you take the chance. Be warned: Larlham expects a huge time-commitment in the tech weeks, of which there were three this time around.
If you are interested in the intersection of theater theory and pratical theater work- take it.
Take it, but only if you're willing to make it your biggest course commitment of the semester.

I would recommend it, but I would be aware of the time commitment outside of class this class requires. You are putting up a show. It felt like some people were incredibly invested and others not so much. I wish everyone had had an equal commitment level. The show turned out great in the end and it was wonderful to be so involved from a production standpoint.

LLOTTT OF TIMEE SPENT REHEARSING, but it all paid off--people thought the production was at a new level of theater and was one of the best, if not the best thing they had seen at Yale, in a large part due to Daniel's directing of staging devices. Enjoyed the entire cast and the process, though stressful, is something I am so thankful to have as part of my college experience.
